author: Reuters Editorial
title: Bank Hapoalim to set aside another $75 million in U.S. tax probe
text: February 28, 2018 / 7:17 AM / Updated 25 minutes ago Bank Hapoalim to set aside another $75 million over U.S. tax investigation Reuters Staff 2 Min Read TEL AVIV (Reuters) - Bank Hapoalim ( POLI.TA ) will set aside an additional $75 million to cover a potential settlement in a U.S. investigation of possible tax evasion by the bank’s clients there, Israel’s largest bank said on Wednesday. Hapoalim said it had determined that more of its clients may be relevant to the investigation by the U.S. Department of Justice. Its provisions for the investigation now stand at $343 million, Hapoalim said in a statement. The bank estimates “that its overall exposure is higher than the amount of the provision it expects to include in its financial reports for 2017,” it said. Hapoalim added that the latest amount to be set aside was not final and could change by the time it publishes its financial results on March 26. Israel’s banking regulator in September ordered lenders to reduce their overseas operations and keep a closer eye on subsidiaries to better comply with risk and compliance rules. The clamp-down came in response to the Hapoalim investigation and similar cases with lenders Leumi ( LUMI.TA ) and Mizrahi Tefahot ( MZTF.TA ). Leumi paid $400 million in fines to U.S. authorities in late 2014. Reporting by Tova Cohen; editing by Steven Scheer and Jason Neely
